awd_titl_txt: CEDAR:  Exploration of Lower-atmosphere Wave Forcing, Vertical Wave Coupling and Their Impacts on the Ionosphere and Thermosphere Variability Using WAM, Lidar and ISR
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to investigate wave forcings originating from the lower atmosphere including their sources, wave interactions and coupling, and their impacts on ionospheric/thermospheric variability. Meteorological sources of wave energy from the lower atmosphere are responsible for producing significant variability in the upper atmosphere, which impacts space weather. Vertical wave coupling is a fundamental atmospheric process that has profound effects on the variability of the ionosphere and thermosphere. 
	This project will utilize existing and ongoing lidar and Incoherent Scatter Radar (ISR) observations to collectively study atmospheric waves in both the neutral atmosphere and ionosphere, and the Whole Atmosphere Model (WAM) to understand and interpret these rich datasets.  In particular, the project will focus on characterizing 1-9 h period gravity waves by comparing observations with simulations in terms of magnitude, vertical and horizontal wavelengths, propagation direction, and latitudinal distribution. The tidal modulation of fast gravity waves will also be studied, and the source regions identified.

por.por_cntn:
This project has significantly advanced the understanding of two most fundamental coupling processes that shape the important Space-Atmosphere-Interaction-Region (SAIR) of Earth, i.e., the vertical wave coupling from below, and magnetosphere-ionosphere-thermosphere coupling from above. Several science discoveries of the work include: 1) Strong and persistent inertial gravity waves in the Antarctic middle atmosphere and their origins; 2) Super-exponential amplitude growth of diurnal and semidiurnal temperature variations in 100-130 km with magnetospheric origin via neutral-ion coupling; 3) A third peak of eastward-propagating planetary waves in the lower thermosphere in temperature and its generation mechanism. 

The main results from these three findings are:

1) Using the Fe lidar measurements at McMurdo, Antarctica, strong and persistent IGWs with periods of 3-10 h are identified in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) with horizontal and vertical wavelengths of thousands of km and 20-30 km, respectively. Similar periods of IGWs are found in the stratosphere but with much smaller scales. Assisted by models, it is found that majority of stratospheric waves are primary waves excited by topography of Antarctic continent, while the MLT waves are secondary waves generated from the body forcing of primary wave breaking. This work highlights that vertical wave coupling is not only through direct propagation, but also through the generation of secondary or even tertiary waves. It helps form a complete picture of Antarctic gravity waves from surface to SAIR. 

2) The classical tidal theory predicts that thermal tides excited by solar radiation are weak at poles, which is what we observed at McMurdo, Antarctica below 100 km. An unexpected phenomenon, however, is the super-exponential increase of diurnal and semidiurnal variations of temperature above 100 km. The CTIPe model shows that such significant growth follows a ring pattern of the auroral oval. The electric convection mapped from the magnetosphere drives ions to move around transferring momentum to neutrals via ion drag. This process induces convergence/divergence leading to upwelling/downwelling and adiabatic cooling/heating in a daily basis. The temperature “tides” are therefore excited, responsible for the fast amplitude growth. It enhances an image that the impacts of Sun-Magnetospere-Ionosphere chain penetrate deeply enough affecting the polar E-region locally.   

3) It is known that eastward propagating planetary waves are generated/amplified by instability of polar night jet. It is not known that whether they can be coupled to the SAIR. For the first time, we report the amplitudes of a group of eastward propagating planetary waves above 100 km, which actually show substantial magnitudes. We use the SD-WACCM to study the mechanism for the third peak and find that the in-situ instability in the MLT likely refuels the residual waves propagating from below and being dissipated. 

Besides the extensive study of the polar atmosphere, we apply high-resolution lidar data in Boulder, Colorado to examine the statistical characteristics of high-to-medium frequency and mesoscale waves in vertical wind and temperature at middle latitude. Theory and data are combined to estimate horizontal wavelength and diffusion coefficient in the MLT for the first time. We take the advantage of newly-developed high-resolution Whole Atmosphere Community Climate Model (WACCM) that resolves mesoscale waves for the model comparison and validation. 

The scientific outcomesinclude 12 peer-reviewed journal papers published in GRL, JGR, and JASTP, 5 peer-reviewed conference proceedings, numerous invited talks and conference presentations. We gain better understanding of the polar waves that play critical roles in determining the mean state and general circulation of the middle and upper atmosphere. This project provides observational databases that help climate models to address the problems of wave forcing and “cold-pole” bias. It forges the close collaborations between experimentalists, theorists, and modelers. It bridges the gaps between neutral dynamics and plasma physics. It urges the team to broaden the horizon and study the SAIR in an integrated system perspective. 

This project has greatly assisted the PI to secure a tenure-track position at a R1 research institute (Clemson University) and launch her academic career as a junior faculty. During the research period, the PI was deployed to the McMurdo station, Antarctica to operate the lidar system and collect data, which were used later on for the project. It has facilitated the education and training of 4 PhD students (3 in University of Colorado Boulder and 1 in Clemson), 4 undergraduate students including 1 female student, and 1 high school student (African American) from a rural community in South Carolina. The students have received systematic education of atmospheric and space physics via taking classes, individual meetings with advisor, and science discussion within the group, and etc. They are fully exposed to the community and world-class scientists via attending workshops, science collaborations with other schools, and visiting national labs such as NCAR. It brings in new blood to the community and trains next-generation atmospheric and space scientists with well-prepared skill set and cutting-edging science views.
